title: Inkberrow Walks

images.title: David Stowell / Inkberrow
images.caption: The village green in the foreground, with the Old Bull, and the tower of St Peter's church behind. The Bull, the fictional Ambridge pub, is supposed to be based on The Old Bull in Inkberrow. In 2006, Inkberrow was awarded the title of Worcestershire Village of the Year.

images.title: Richard  Dunn / Inkberrow Church
images.caption: Inkberrow Church as seen from Gooms Hill Farm. The current building at the site is believed to date from the 13th Century. During the Civil War, in 1645, Charles I left his maps in the church, after staying the night at the vicarage.

images.title: Colin Craig / Millennium trail
images.caption: A pond forming part of Inkberrow's Millennium trail.

images.title: Claire Seyler / View from Millennium Seat at Inkberrow's Millennium Green
images.caption: View from Millennium Seat at the Millennium Green. The Green is 9 acres of meadows maintained by volunteers. Here you can sit at the top of the hill and enjoy the views.

images.title: Chris Allen / Former windmill - Holberrow Green
images.caption: Holberrow Green Mill

images.title: Richard Croft / Coughton Court
images.caption: Coughton Court. Garden front of the historic home of the Throckmorton family since 1412

description: This pretty Worcestershire village includes a picturesque village green, a historic church and a fine local pub. The settlement is notable as the model for Ambridge, the setting of BBC Radio 4's long-running series The Archers. This walk from the village explores the Millennium Green before following a section of the Warwickshire Millennium Way through the countryside to Coughton Court. The walk starts in the village where you can first enjoy a stroll around the Millennium Green. Here you'll find a pleasant boardwalk circuit taking you around a medieval moat. After exploring the green head west through the village to pick up the Warwickshire Millennium Way. You can follow this waymarked footpath north towards Morton Underhill and Holberrow Green. The route continues east towards Cladswell where you pick up the Monarch's Way and follow it east past Coughton Park to Coughton Hall. The fine Tudor mansion includes a walled garden, lake, knot garden, vegetable garden, orchard and bog garden.
